Posts.Content: No worries Carol, I so know where you are!!  Staging in breast cancer is the same for all kinds of cancer including DCIS so stage one is that and the very best kind. Hormone positive is good as prognosis is better and also because it offers a whole additional treatment range as it means the cancer needs hormones to grow and so you starve it of them....... Cancer has some very scary words in simple conversations, words like invasive and aggressive are quite bullying type words as they have a physical impact on your body just thinking about them, but they are simply the descriptive terms used and you definitely do not sound aggressive in any way shape or form. My advise is to never make a decision in a state of fear or panic, cancer , even when mega aggressive does not spread like a rash, most cancers have been growing for years, unnoticed, so taking a few days or even a week to get to grips with it and make decisions that are right for you will not make any difference to your prognosis, which I have to say sounds extremely positive...and people on here know I don´t use that word lightly!!!   xxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey, sorry you are here again - I am guessing you are quite young and not near menopause?  In that case removing your ovaries is a fairly common route to go as hormone dependent xancers depend on oestrogen and progesterone, both released by ovaries and then stored in your body or generated from fat post menopause, which is where the oestrogen blockers come in after menopause.......so the surgery idea seems a good one for you esp if you cannot take Tamoxifen, then you would be able to take other aromatase inhibitors post surgery I think which may not clash with your other medication.  I would ask questions about your treatment and prevention methods after removal of ovaries before you make a decision, but from my limited knowledge it makes sense to me. Posts.Title: Intro - Diagnosis Day

Posts.Content: Hi Lyn - I wish medics would not do this as it just worries people..... I had two MRI scans (not CT as cannot tolerate contrast) and they showed up various things, some changes in the non cancer breast and elsewhere.  I had further tests and immediately afterwards was told it is NOT cancer but still do not know what it actually is and in many cases people have things show up that are NOT cancer, its one of the downsides of scans so please don´t write yourself off yet!! It does not mean is has to be cancer, arthritis shows up, as does spinal disc problems and until they are read by a specialist technician no one knows exactly what these are...... I would ask lots of questions like What makes you think it might be cancer? What else could it be? What does it mean if it is cancer? Is it a new primary or a secondary? What is the treatment? Why do you want to delay surgery? Bastard disease this and the biggest challenge is a mental one... .

Posts.Content: Info below from Business Week magazine The next new treatment for breast, colon and prostate cancers, among others, may be a diabetes drug first approved in 1958. Metformin, the most commonly used medicine to lower blood- sugar, is the subject of about 50 cancer studies globally, according to U.S. government clinical trial information compiled by Bloomberg. The research began after scientists found metformin prevented tumors in mice and that diabetics were less likely to develop a malignancy if they were taking the 5 cents- a-day pill than other diabetes medications. The medicine is dispensed about 120 million times annually, according to a 2010 report in the journal Molecular Cancer Therapeutics. If the latest trials on breast and other tumors are successful, the drug could become a cheap weapon in the fight against a myriad of diseases including pancreatic and ovarian cancers. All told, cancer kills one in eight people and is the second-leading cause of death in most developed nations. “The hope is that if it does show safety and efficacy, it would be available in a cost-effective way,” said Chandini Portteus, vice president of research, evaluation and scientific programs at Susan G. Komen for the Cure, a Dallas-based breast cancer advocacy group. “It would be wonderful for patients if we had something that we knew worked and was safe and low- cost.” The organization has spent about $10 million investigating metformin for breast cancer, Portteus said. “We have to turn over every single rock to determine what the options are for patients who need them.” Millions of Deaths Global cancer deaths will climb to 13.1 million by 2030 from 7.6 million in 2008, the Geneva-based World Health Organization said in February. Cancer costs totaled $124.6 billion in the U.S. alone in 2010, according to the National Cancer Institute. Newer, more targeted drug therapies, such as Dendreon Corp. (DNDN)’s $93,000-a-year Provenge for prostate cancer, may add only a few months of life. Metformin was the seventh most-dispensed medicine in the U.S. in 2011, according to a list published by IMS Institute for Healthcare Informatics in April that ranked a group of painkillers that includes Vicodin as the most-prescribed. A pack of 84 500-milligram tablets of the diabetes pill, taken twice daily, costs the U.K.’s National Health Service 1.37 pounds, or the equivalent of about 3 pence (5 U.S. cents) a day. The MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston is studying metformin in at least eight trials, according to a National Institutes of Health online database. ‘Safe and Cheap’ “It is safe and it is cheap,” said Donghui Li, an epidemiologist and professor of medicine at the center. “It reduces the risk and has better survival” in studies she’s done in pancreatic cancer patients. Patients who had taken metformin had a 60 percent lower risk of developing pancreatic cancer, according to a case- control study Li published in 2009 in which she compared cancer patients taking metformin against people not on metformin. Metformin didn’t benefit patients whose pancreatic cancer had already spread to other tissues, Li reported this year in the journal Clinical Cancer Research. Those patients whose malignancies were confined to the pancreas survived longer if they were on metformin -- an average of 15 months, or four months more than patients not taking the drug, she found. More research is needed to confirm those benefits in patients as their disease is developing, Li said. “I got a lot of calls from patients and other clinicians, but I told them I cannot give them a recommendation,” she said. Insulin Levels Lewis Cantley, director of the Cancer Center at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston, a hospital affiliated with Harvard Medical School, does have a suggestion for doctors who diagnose and treat diabetics: Test patients’ insulin levels in addition to blood sugar. People whose insulin levels are high should either take metformin or increase their exercise and control their diets by reducing the amount of carbohydrates eaten, Cantley said. “That will have a huge impact in preventing you from getting cancer,” said Cantley, who trained as a biochemist and biophysicist, in an interview. “It may even slow down the growth of the cancer you already have.”

Posts.Title: Chemo - Should I have it or not?

Posts.Content: Poor you - I found this for you shelley from a reputable site........ Abraxane uses albumin, which is a human protein, in conjunction with pacitaxel to deliver the treatment to the cancerous cells. It is easier to do this when albumin is used because there are receptors for this protein on the surface of the cells of the tumors. This makes it easier for the molecules of the drug to bind with them and start to work effectively. Inside the tumor, there is a protein called SPARC that supplied the tumor with the nutrients it needs to grow. When Abraxane bonds with the cells, it cuts off this supply of nutrients. There are no chemical solvents in Abraxane, which means that patients do not need to take a regimen of medication before receiving treatment to combat the effects of the chemicals on the body. This drug has been approved for use in the treatment of breast cancer in almost all countries of the world.

There is a grief cycle to go through and as you go through it the ebbs and flows get farther apart......There IS evidence that stress makes people more prone to cancer - and I think the pressure to be positive is more an expression of the needs of others rather than an essential to regaining health!  So after that long meander, my message is to say feel what you are feeling, don´t judge yourself but be kind instead.........I am glad you came on here to tell us and now feel a bit supported... xx.

Posts.Content: This is an extract from info on About Breast Cancer which is accurate - don´t get too worried about it as some countries do it as standard tests.....but it also seems to vary according to which actual pice of tissue was studied - I had one which was 90% (ie MEGA high) and another one which was 20%.....one heck of a difference yet same cancer and same breast............ Copied and pasted info   The researchers agreed that high levels of Ki-67 indicate an aggressive tumor and predict a poor prognosis. A British study found that breast cancers could vary in regards to hormone-sensitivity, lymph node status (positive or negative), but if the tumor tested positive with high levels of Ki-67, the risk of recurrence was higher than average. Do I Need The Ki-67 Tumor Marker Test? If your cancer appears to be aggressive, your doctor may order this test to see if Ki-67 is affecting your tumor growth. Other tests must also be done for hormone receptors, HER2 - neu and metastasis, and these results, along with your Ki-67 Labeling Index (test score) will affect your treatment plan. Benefits of The Ki-67 Tumor Marker Test A breast tumor that scores high for Ki-67 is made of cells that are rapidly dividing and growing. Chemotherapy drugs target cells that are growing beyond the normal rate, and so these drugs can be effective on aggressive cancers. Knowing your Ki-67 score helps you and your doctor decide what treatment will work best for you. Balancing Prognosis With Your Response to Treatment A study in the Journal of Clinical Oncology found that tumors that had higher levels of Ki-67 had a good response to chemotherapy. This study noted that a high index of Ki-67 usually means a poor prognosis (shorter survival), but if the cancer responds particularly well to appropriate chemotherapy, long-term survival is achievable. They also speculate that if the Ki-67 test were done according to consistent standards, the results of a Ki-67 test might be helpful in determining whether or not neoadjuvant chemotherapy (given before surgery) would be effective for some tumors.

Posts.Content: Who is this doctor - GOD?  No wonder you are shocked and shaken up but who the hell is she, there is loads and loads of evidence out there that says that breast cancer treatment is evolving and improving all the time and any statistics the doctors have to refer to are always 5 years out of date, as they have to be when talking about 5 year survival.  Think about how much you have heard over the last 5 years re treatment improvements and how in 2014 to 2015 they reckon BC will be sub-divided in to loads of categories when they plan treatments....... I know people who were very high risk, surgery did not get all the tumour out first time round and they had the works, 5 years on, alive, well, smoking (!) and cancer free.......... Sorry but I too am blazing mad at her arrogance as it is not as cut and dried as that and telling you this could make i a self fulfilling prophecy........ . SOME breast cancer may be more likely to return before 5 years but others aren´t - look at Olivia Newton John, how long ago was her cancer?  It is definitely NOT true that bc definitely returns at 2 to 5 year intervals...... My advice is do what you most want to do right now........and please remember you are NOT in need of palliative treatment at the moment and may not be for 10 to 15 years as by the time you get to year 5 there will be new treatments etc etc....... There is so much info and evidence out there about the impact of thoughts and belief on health, don´t let her rather gloomy outlook affect you, live your life and trust in how you feel.....you are giving this woman (and she is only a fallible human being with medical training nothing more than that, not a mega psychic etc...) far too much power............. I was given two lots of statistics by different oncologists, both well regarded, one said 30% chance surviving 5 years the other one said 50%, that alone is 66% difference and with treatment I don´t think either will be true.....prove her wrong and send her a card as you hit each anniversary - yah boo sucks to you, I made it.......   Take care xxxx
